--- title: 'NLP Course 2 Week 1 Lesson : Building The Model - Lecture Exercise 01' jupyter: python3 --- Estimated Time: 10 minutes # Vocabulary Creation Create a tiny vocabulary from a tiny corpus It's time to start small ! ### Imports and Data ::: {#c870fffb .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} # imports import re # regular expression library; for tokenization of words from collections import Counter # collections library; counter: dict subclass for counting hashable objects import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # for data visualization ``` ::: ::: {#92ca4388 .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} # the tiny corpus of text ! text = 'red pink pink blue blue yellow ORANGE BLUE BLUE PINK' # ðŸŒˆ print(text) print('string length : ',len(text)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` red pink pink blue blue yellow ORANGE BLUE BLUE PINK string length : 52 ``` ::: ::: ### Preprocessing ::: {#a51fcdec .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} # convert all letters to lower case text_lowercase = text.lower() print(text_lowercase) print('string length : ',len(text_lowercase)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` red pink pink blue blue yellow orange blue blue pink string length : 52 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#cf42a0bf .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} # some regex to tokenize the string to words and return them in a list words = re.findall(r'\w+', text_lowercase) print(words) print('count : ',len(words)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ['red', 'pink', 'pink', 'blue', 'blue', 'yellow', 'orange', 'blue', 'blue', 'pink'] count : 10 ``` ::: ::: ### Create Vocabulary Option 1 : A set of distinct words from the text ::: {#e53331fc .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} # create vocab vocab = set(words) print(vocab) print('count : ',len(vocab)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` {'red', 'yellow', 'pink', 'orange', 'blue'} count : 5 ``` ::: ::: ### Add Information with Word Counts Option 2 : Two alternatives for including the word count as well ::: {#6cfdc3a9 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} # create vocab including word count counts_a = dict() for w in words: counts_a[w] = counts_a.get(w,0)+1 print(counts_a) print('count : ',len(counts_a)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` {'red': 1, 'pink': 3, 'blue': 4, 'yellow': 1, 'orange': 1} count : 5 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#b4714dce .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} # create vocab including word count using collections.Counter counts_b = dict() counts_b = Counter(words) print(counts_b) print('count : ',len(counts_b)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Counter({'blue': 4, 'pink': 3, 'red': 1, 'yellow': 1, 'orange': 1}) count : 5 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#45a48ef2 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} # barchart of sorted word counts d = {'blue': counts_b['blue'], 'pink': counts_b['pink'], 'red': counts_b['red'], 'yellow': counts_b['yellow'], 'orange': counts_b['orange']} plt.bar(range(len(d)), list(d.values()), align='center', color=d.keys()) _ = plt.xticks(range(len(d)), list(d.keys())) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](lab01_files/figure-html/cell-9-output-1.png){width=571 height=411} ::: ::: ### Ungraded Exercise Note that `counts_b`, above, returned by `collections.Counter` is sorted by word count Can you modify the tiny corpus of ***text*** so that a new color appears between ***pink*** and ***red*** in `counts_b` ? Do you need to run all the cells again, or just specific ones ? ::: {#2da5fc8a .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} print('counts_b : ', counts_b) print('count : ', len(counts_b)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` counts_b : Counter({'blue': 4, 'pink': 3, 'red': 1, 'yellow': 1, 'orange': 1}) count : 5 ``` ::: ::: Expected Outcome: counts_b : Counter({'blue': 4, 'pink': 3, **'your_new_color_here': 2**, red': 1, 'yellow': 1, 'orange': 1})
count : 6 ### Summary This is a tiny example but the methodology scales very well.
In the assignment you will create a large vocabulary of thousands of words, from a corpus
of tens of thousands or words! But the mechanics are exactly the same.
The only extra things to pay attention to should be; run time, memory management and the vocab data structure.
So the choice of approach used in code blocks `counts_a` vs `counts_b`, above, will be important.
